title: Aerospike Rule Template
text:
This document provides the standardized template and guidelines for contributing new health check rules to the Aerospike Health and Performance Report. Following this template ensures that your rule integrates seamlessly with the automated reporting engine.


Use the following structure for your rule file (e.g., rules/your_check_name.py).
import sqlite3
import pandas as pd

# --- Metadata ---
# ID: {X.y} (e.g., 5.a)
# Title: Descriptive Name

def run_check(db_path="aerospike_health.db"):
    """
    Executes the health check against the local SQLite database.
    
    Returns:
        dict: {
            "id": str,          # The unique identifier (e.g., "5.a")
            "name": str,        # The display name of the rule
            "status": str,      # PASS, WARNING, CRITICAL, or ‚ö†Ô∏è DATA MISSING
            "message": str,     # Human-readable findings
            "remediation": str  # Specific steps to resolve the issue
        }
    """
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_path)
    
    try:
        # 1. Query Logic
        # df = pd.read_sql_query("SELECT ...", conn)
        
        # 2. Handle Missing Data
        # if df.empty:
        #     return {
        #         "id": "X.y",
        #         "name": "Rule Name",
        #         "status": "‚ö†Ô∏è DATA MISSING",
        #         "message": "Telemetry not found.",
        #         "remediation": "Run 'asadm -e info' to collect missing metrics."
        #     }
        
        # 3. Success Case
        return {
            "id": "X.y",
            "name": "Your Rule Name",
            "status": "PASS",
            "message": "Check completed successfully.",
            "remediation": "None required."
        }
        
    except Exception as e:
        return {
            "id": "X.y",
            "name": "Your Rule Name",
            "status": "CRITICAL",
            "message": f"An error occurred: {str(e)}",
            "remediation": "Review logs and database schema."
        }
    finally:
        conn.close()




Return Schema: Every rule must return a dictionary with keys: id, name, status, message, and remediation.
Error Handling: Use try...except...finally to ensure the reporting engine continues running even if a specific rule fails.
Read-Only: Rules should only read from the database.







Status
Meaning




PASS
Healthy thresholds.


WARNING
Threshold exceeded, but operational.


CRITICAL
Risk of data loss or instability.


‚ö†Ô∏è DATA MISSING
Telemetry lacks required metrics.

title: Aerospike Rule Template
text:
Use the following structure for your rule file (e.g., rules/your_check_name.py).
import sqlite3
import pandas as pd

# --- Metadata ---
# ID: {X.y} (e.g., 5.a)
# Title: Descriptive Name

def run_check(db_path="aerospike_health.db"):
    """
    Executes the health check against the local SQLite database.
    
    Returns:
        dict: {
            "id": str,          # The unique identifier (e.g., "5.a")
            "name": str,        # The display name of the rule
            "status": str,      # PASS, WARNING, CRITICAL, or ‚ö†Ô∏è DATA MISSING
            "message": str,     # Human-readable findings
            "remediation": str  # Specific steps to resolve the issue
        }
    """
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_path)
    
    try:
        # 1. Query Logic
        # df = pd.read_sql_query("SELECT ...", conn)
        
        # 2. Handle Missing Data
        # if df.empty:
        #     return {
        #         "id": "X.y",
        #         "name": "Rule Name",
        #         "status": "‚ö†Ô∏è DATA MISSING",
        #         "message": "Telemetry not found.",
        #         "remediation": "Run 'asadm -e info' to collect missing metrics."
        #     }
        
        # 3. Success Case
        return {
            "id": "X.y",
            "name": "Your Rule Name",
            "status": "PASS",
            "message": "Check completed successfully.",
            "remediation": "None required."
        }
        
    except Exception as e:
        return {
            "id": "X.y",
            "name": "Your Rule Name",
            "status": "CRITICAL",
            "message": f"An error occurred: {str(e)}",
            "remediation": "Review logs and database schema."
        }
    finally:
        conn.close()

title: Aerospike Rule Template
text:
Return Schema: Every rule must return a dictionary with keys: id, name, status, message, and remediation.
Error Handling: Use try...except...finally to ensure the reporting engine continues running even if a specific rule fails.
Read-Only: Rules should only read from the database.

title: Aerospike Health and Performance Report
text:
TAM Overview
The cluster state is derived from telemetry provided in the {bundle_display} bundle. This assessment focuses on configuration symmetry, performance outliers, and hardware support.

title: Aerospike Health and Performance Report
text:
TAM Assessment Scope
The findings below are based on a point-in-time snapshot provided in the source bundle. Remediation steps are prioritized by their impact on cluster stability and performance.
